10.84.text: What happens when a university and local communities work together?

15.12.text: What knowledge and stories get unlocked?

20.24.text: Through Know Your Bristol on the move

24.72.text: have been working with university researchers

27.52.text: developing ways to unlock stories about heritage

32.40.text: That we can all learn from, enjoy and share.

36.80.text: At the heart of the venture, have been new tools.

40.04.text: An interactive mobile app called, Map Your Bristol

43.80.text: and the Know Your Bristol bus. An expanding, mobile classroom.

49.92.text: One of the first places the tools were used

52.20.text: was in a neighbourhood in north Bristol.

57.76.text:
Today we have rocked up to a street party, 
we have been doing some oral history interviews

61.76.text: we have been experimenting with a new app we’re developing

65.20.text:
Which is really a chance for communities, 
schools, streets, neighbours

70.44.text: to upload content onto the website

74.00.text:
So what I’m going to be doing is adding a new location 
and some photos to the Map Your Bristol app.

80.20.text:
Its from a photo we took earlier 
so I can do that from our camera roll

84.24.text: We know the year, it was 1917, so I’m going to pop that in there

88.52.text:
Now ideally people can comment on that, add their own thoughts, 
any new photographs or own stories that they want to add.

94.44.text: Stuff gets uploaded on to these sites, and we have this

98.44.text: multi-faceted map of Bristol community histories.

102.60.text: We create history, we create culture, together.

107.60.text:
It’s a brilliant record of what life is like for real Bristolian people, 
how our city is, and how it's changing.

118.24.text: At the Bristol Record Office, Know Your Bristol On The Move

121.84.text:
has been helping to mobilise volunteers 
to help with the digitisation of postcards from a historic collection.

129.40.text: The Vaughan Collection was about 11,000 postcards

133.56.text: we’ve been running in collaboration with the Bristol Record Office

137.96.text: to train and support volunteers, who have been coming in

142.44.text: and actually properly cataloguing, this immense local history.

146.24.text: We ask our volunteers to search through the catalogue of postcards, to identify

153.68.text: maybe just an area of Bristol, or a subject within the catalogue that interests them

161.72.text:
Adding that to the Know Your Place website,
  where we have a with a dedicated layer.

166.32.text: This wonderful visual catalogue of Bristol, through postcards.

173.72.text: is now available on Know Your Place, with each postcard fixed to its place on the map.

182.68.text: Not all the community collaborations feature the use of the Map Your Bristol Mobile app.

188.36.text: We’ve got a group of people, who are all to do with Single Parent Action Network

193.96.text:
and together we are researching the history of women’s work
in the local area.

198.92.text: For this strand, I felt like the website was quite distant from the work we were doing

205.72.text:
and I wanted to do something that was very hands on,
 a bit more low tech

210.52.text:
and we're making an exhibition
which is going to be at the SILAI centre.

215.64.text:
We realised when we started it that there weren’t
 a lot of women involved in the history of Bristol.

221.60.text:
We decided then that we would need to put some
 women’s history on the map, it's really important.

228.48.text: You've got a thing on the wall there about a walk around Bristol with different things relevant to women and the challenges they have had in Bristol.

239.04.text: If possible I would like to go and see some of those things.

242.76.text:
The project has also helped reconnect communities
with lost archives.

248.48.text:
Tapes that were made about 40 years ago
by people in Knowle West

253.16.text: were taken to the National Film Archive

256.28.text:
and kept in the right temperature for all those years.
Now money has been found

261.48.text: as part of the University of Bristol project, to have them digitised.

266.16.text:
This week we have actually been able to show people.
 We’re having an installation, we’re showing all of the footage

272.12.text:
in its entirety on a large screen. We have also got students 
working with the footage to create short sequences

278.96.text: and we have a whole range of different themes in the Knowle West media training centre

284.32.text:
where community members can come in and watch the footage
 and contribute their own information and knowledge about the material.

291.48.text:
It's an archive of what people were like, how they lived, 
what their thoughts, views and opinions were at that time.

298.16.text:
The themes and the politics haven’t changed
 and it really demonstrates how vital and current and important the material still is.

307.44.text: As part of the project the Map Your Bristol app is being used as a learning tool in schools.

314.84.text:
We wanted to work with the schools 
because of the opportunity provided by the curriculum

318.96.text:
We already knew that some 
were working with the Know Your Place website.

323.96.text: We’re going to ask them to think about personal stories

329.12.text: allow them to do some research and that’s what’s going to be uploaded.

334.88.text:
I’ve got some deeds from the house to say where 
it was going to be built and then I have got a

339.64.text:
office copy which says it was 10 shillings in 1890
 on the 2nd of October.

347.32.text: The value I feel is that so many students do not appreciate that they are history

354.08.text: and that their families are significant and that history isn’t just about

358.16.text: people that they would consider to be famous

361.20.text: that actually, their human achievement is worth recognising.

371.64.text: Know Your Bristol on the move has started a whole series of fascinating conversations

376.48.text: between researchers and a whole set of communities across Bristol.

381.60.text: These relationships are part of an expanding network

384.96.text: helping both university and communities create knowledge

389.24.text: and continue to discover and share Bristol’s history, culture and heritage.

397.16.text: Its just jaw dropping, when you look at what's there

402.64.text: Sometimes you can be proud about family history and your

406.16.text: ancestors and what they have achieved in their lifetime.

412.08.text: I just think its nice to know where we’ve come from

415.92.text: I sometimes think it helps to know where were going in our future as well.
